title.narrative: Wildlife Without Borders - Africa

description.narrative: Capacity Building for Reduced Bushmeat Exploitation in Eastern Africa

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: USAID-Africa Small Grants

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to strengthen capacity to reduce bushmeat off take in and around key protected areas in Eastern Africa through a network of organizations and individuals working collaboratively to mobilize resources, share information, set priorities, and apply solutions. As a cooperative agreement between WCS and the USFWS, the project will catalyze action and guide activities to curtail illegal hunting and trade in bushmeat by developing a network (Bushmeat-free Eastern Africa Network, BEAN) of institutions, organizations, and individuals working together to resolve the problem of unsustainable bushmeat exploitation, and strengthen capacity for bushmeat monitoring in countries of Eastern Africa. USFWS will provide guidance, technical expertise, and financial support to BEAN. WCS-will provide technical support to the BEAN, oversee implementation of BEAN activities, and facilitate grant management and reporting obligations. BEAN will be implemented by a Director based at WCS-Uganda country program offices in Kampala reporting directly to WCS New York, USFWS, the BEAN Team, and to key partners within the region.

description.narrative: The grantee will expand the coverage and effectiveness of ranger patrols to reduce poaching in Mpus Kutuk Community Conservancy in Kenyas northern rangelands through the provision of a vehicle to enhance ranger mobility and response, facilitate the coordination of cross-conservancy patrols, improve elephant monitoring. title.narrative: African Elephant Conservation Fund

description.narrative: This grant will support joint law enforcement efforts of the Mount Kenya Trust and Kenya Wildlife Service to decrease poaching of elephants and other illegal activities on the slopes of Mount Kenya. Specific activities will include training and supporting patrol teams to conduct anti-poaching patrols, collect information on poaching activities (including MIKE data) and wildlife presence (to be analyzed in a spatially explicit database), combat illegal land clearing, logging, and cultivation within the park, construct housing for wildlife personnel, and support outreach activities including wildlife clubs in schools and liaison with forest associations and government agencies.

title.narrative: Reintroduction of Black Rhinos to Sera Wildlife Conservancy, Kenya

description.narrative: This project will assist with the costs of establishing the first eastern black rhino reintroduction site on community-owned land in Kenya. The site has been fenced to include a closed rhino sanctuary of 120 km2, and has been approved to receive rhinos from the national authority, Kenya Wildlife Services, in 2014. Specific activities will include 1) completion of the electric fencing, gates, and ranger bases and accommodation, 2) equipping rangers with vehicles and communications equipment and 3) conducting ground and air patrols, 4) construct temporary holding pens for rhinos on site, 5) translocate rhinos from elsewhere in Kenya, install tracking equipment, and 6) release and track the animals and conduct post-release monitoring and veterinary interventions, as necessary.

title.narrative: Rhino & Tiger Conservation Fund

description.narrative: Funds will provide support for essential security operations and rhino monitoring for eastern black rhinos in Chyulu Hills National Park in Kenya. Specific activities will include constructing a new ranger base in an area that was previously difficult to secure, providing basic and advanced ranger training for the community scouts, deploying community scouts for general security and specialized scouts for rhino monitoring, maintaining a network of satellite camera traps and the rhino identification database, and deploying tracking equipment on one or more rhinos to better understand their behavior and habitat use.

title.narrative: Enhancing elephant security in community lands in the Kenya-Tanzania Borderlands

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to conserve large free-ranging elephant populations in the community lands of the Rombo-Chalal and the Loita-South Rift borderland areas of Kenya by building a network of community scouts and developing strategies to overcome the challenges of cross border collaboration. The project is intended to conserve migrating elephants by addressing the impacts of poaching and cross-border conflict. Specific activities include: 1) support for the community scout network including training, equipment, development of SMART (Spatial Monitoring and Reporting Tool) system and a monitoring database to enhance patrolling; and 2) facilitation of cross border collaboration through development of protocols, joint patrols, information sharing and meetings to improve anti-poaching efforts.

title.narrative: Wildife Without Borders-Critically Endangered Animals

description.narrative: This project will provide scientific data useful for rationale management and conservation of the endangered scalloped hammerhead shark populations in Kenya. Specific objectives include: (1) Capacity building through training of relevant government agencies to facilitate identification of landed species, imparting skills for basic morphometric measurements, sexing and staging of the landed species including the scalloped hammerhead, and improving reporting on catch and landings of sharks; (2) Assessment of catch composition and structure of the scalloped hammerhead sharks on the north coast of Kenya with the aim to describe the landed size, structure, sex composition, morphometric relationships and demographic rates of the species (viz. growth and mortality rates); (3) Determination of biological information including; reproductive biology and feeding ecology of the scalloped hammerhead sharks on the north coast of Kenya.

title.narrative: Community based conservation of wild African elephant in the Matthews and Ndoto mountain ecosystems, northern Kenya

description.narrative: This project supports community scouts, enabling them to conduct anti-poaching patrols and to secure access to water for elephants and other wildlife, thereby alleviating conflict with livestock. It will develop scout capacity, expand their coverage, and increase monitoring ecosystem health (vegetation quality, wildlife densities, and water availability) in the Mathews and Ndoto mountain ranges in Kenya's arid northern rangelands.

title.narrative: Strengthening Marine Turtle Conservation Efforts along the Kenyan Coast

description.narrative: The recipient will carry out a sea turtle bycatch release program with up to 350 local artisanal fishers; conduct anti-poaching patrols along 20 km of nesting beach within and north and south of Watamu Marine National Park; conduct outreach and awareness sessions with local communities; and conduct training workshops for up to 30 Kenya Wildlife Service staff on marine ecology, coastal zone management and conservation principles.

title.narrative: Enhancing the African Elephant Database

description.narrative: In order to provide decision-makers with the most up-to-date information on the status of African elephant populations across 37 range states, funds will support the operating costs of the African Elephant database and the 2016 update to the IUCN African Elephant Status Report. This update will categorize 2015 and 2016 aerial survey data by survey type, quality and reliability of the estimates. Funds also support the online interface where members of the public and experts can access information about elephant populations and distribution.

title.narrative: Mbulia elephant fence to secure dry season habitat within the Tsavo Conservation Area

description.narrative: Due to human-elephant conflict, the Kenya Wildlife Service has decided to fence portions of Tsavo West National Park. People living in Mbulia Group Ranch on the southern boundary with the park have dedicated a portion (46km2) of their land to wildlife habitat and have invested in wildlife-based livelihoods. This project will support the community-led initiative to pay for an 18km extension of the fence so that the Mbulia wildlife habitat will be included within the elephant fence and can continue to be an integral part of the Tsavo complex.

title.narrative: Building Capacity for Canine Anti-Trafficking and Anti-Poaching in Africa and Asia

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support wildlife security efforts in Africa by providing benchmarks for professional development of canine law enforcement programs. This project is intended to conserve elephants and other select species targeted by the illegal commercial trade in wildlife. Specific activities include: (1) Production and printing of curriculum materials to assist dog handlers in Africa and Asia; (2) compilation of existing training videos and production of new videos demonstrating best practices techniques to improve the efficacy of dog programs; (3) site visits to facilitate project staff and leaders to interact with and learn from high functioning dog programs; and (4) basic equipment for health and diagnostics at every canine program site to improve the health and well-being of the dogs.

title.narrative: Assessing elephant habitat use and offering increased protection and connectivity within the Imenti and Lower Imenti Forest Reserves of Mount Kenya

description.narrative: This project works to secure habitat for elephants on the slopes of Mount Kenya, which has become increasingly isolated and fragmented by human settlement and agriculture. To reduce conflict between elephants and farmers and to increase protection, other donors and local stakeholders are building a fence around the perimeter of the remaining montane forest; however, pathways and corridors need to be identified, preserved, and protected in order to allow elephant movement seasonally between the mountain and lower altitude range. Specific activities will include assessing current elephant distribution, pathways, and habitat use in order to recommend appropriate passage and road-crossing structures, and assessing and maintaining fences that protect remaining habitat.

title.narrative: Frontline protection of at-risk elephant populations in the Laikipia-Samburu Ecosystem

description.narrative: This project seeks to reduce elephant poaching within a specific region of the Laikipia Samburu Ecosystem through the establishment of a mobile Rapid Response Team (RRT) of highly trained rangers in Laikipia West and North Constituencies, complementing the RRT founded at Ol Pejeta Conservancy with previous USFWS support. These mobile response teams undertake regular patrols, follow up on information and pro-actively prevent incidents from occurring. They complement the existing North Kenya Policing Strategy and will operate in support of the Kenya Wildlife Service and the National Police Service to bring security to both wildlife and people.

description.narrative: Funds will be used to minimize conflict with local farmers in the farming communities of Namelok and Isinet between Amboseli, Chyulu Hills and Tsavo West National Parks. Specific activity will include the construction of a 59-km electric fence to keep elephants inside wildlife-tolerant areas. According to the impact assessment and community consultation, this fence will prevent elephants from entering agricultural land and, in exchange, the community will tolerate elephant movement through existing corridors and into seasonal dispersal areas in order to minimize conflict and facilitate coexistence.Ensuring long-term viability of elephants through exclusion fencing to permanently reduce human-elephant conflict in the Greater Amboseli Ecosystem, Kenya

title.narrative: Preparing the Chyulu Hills National Park in Kenya for inbound translocation of rhinos

description.narrative: Human population pressure, infrastructure development, and poaching have pushed the Chyulu Hills National Park black rhino population down to fewer than ten individuals. The habitat shared by Chyulu NP and Mbirikani Group Ranch is capable of supporting a much larger population, so Kenya Wildlife Services intends to fortify the area into an Intensive Protection Zone (IPZ) and translocate rhinos in to the area from other populations in Kenya to boost this declining population and stimulate recovery. Funds will be used to help cover operating costs for anti-poaching security, including running costs for daily and extended patrols, salaries and rations, vehicle fuel and running costs, and costs related to investigation and prosecution of poachers.

title.narrative: Decreasing human-elephant conflict in West Laikipia to manageable levels

description.narrative: This project aims to reduce conflict between humans and elephants in Laikipia County incentral Kenya and home to Kenyas second largest elephant population. The project will separate elephants from agriculture where possible through the repair and fortification of an elephant-proof fence. Activities will include conducting outreach with residents to explain the purpose of the fence and to get buy-in and commitment necessary for long-term upkeep, improving the alignment so that wildlife-friendly properties are on one side (north and east of the fence) and incompatible agriculture is on the other side (south and west), repairing the old fence and fortifying it, establishing a fence maintenance team to prevent intentional fence destruction by people, and repair breakage where it occurs.

title.narrative: Enhancing the recovery and conservation of eastern black rhinos through resilient habitat management in partnership with local communities at Sera Wildlife Conservancy, Kenya

description.narrative: Kenya is home to more than 75% of the surviving eastern black rhinos (Diceros bicornis michaeli). In 2015, USFWS supported the first reintroduction of rhinos in Kenya onto community land, in Sera Wildlife Conservancy in northern Kenya. The founder population has increased to 15 animals, has not suffered any poaching, and the area has the potential to support as many as 35 rhinos. The population could also expand onto neighboring community conservancies, if they can be secured. Funds are requested for operational costs of anti-poaching and security patrols on and around Sera for 2018-2019, and developing and implementing plans to expand the rhino sanctuary for the long-term.

title.narrative: IMPROVED SECURITY AND CONSERVATION OF ELEPHANTS IN TSAVO, KENYA

description.narrative: In partnership with Tsavo Trust. The purpose of this project is to maintain the integrity of Kenyas single largest elephant population, distributed across several protected areas near the border with Tanzania. Known as the Tsavo Conservation Area, the landscape supported around 40,000 elephants in the 1960s before poaching and other pressures reduced the population to around 6,400 animals in 1988. Now estimated between 12,000 and 14,000 individuals, the Tsavo population is known for containing a small number of super tuskers, iconic elephants that carry exceptionally large ivory and are increasingly rare across the continent. The project places particular emphasis on monitoring these individuals to deter targeted poaching and to highlight the need to secure habitat and connectivity in the broader ecosystem. Specific activities include: (1) aerial monitoring and reconnaissance to identify poaching camps and to track individual elephants with large ivory; (2) support for field-based anti-poaching operations, including protection units, ranger infrastructure development, and ranger training; and (3) support for local communities adjacent to the protected areas through the development of community wildlife conservancies, human-elephant conflict mitigation strategies, and tourism partnerships.

title.narrative: PRIVATE-SECTOR SUPPORT FOR THE DELIVERY OF KENYA S BLACK RHINO ACTION PLAN

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support a conservation effort in Ol Jogi Conservancy, Borana.Conservancy, Lewa Wildlife Conservancy, and on the Association of Private and Community Land.Rhino Sanctuaries in Kenya by strengthening rhinoceros protection, biological monitoring, and.coordination. This project is intended to conserve the Eastern black rhinoceros by addressing the impacts.of rhinoceros poaching, the need for biological management for rhinoceros, and the new threats to the.Conservancies income generation due to the loss of revenue from tourism and other global economic.factors because of COVID-19. Specific activities include: (1) increasing rhinoceros protection; (2).monitoring and management of rhinoceros populations in order to optimize growth, expand their range,.and maintain genetic diversity; and (3) coordinating and collaborating on effective project management.with private and community land conservancies as a contribution to the Kenya Black Rhino Action Plan.2022-2026.

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support a conservation effort in Tsavo West National Park, Kenya by enhancing security, conducting monitoring, and supporting park management to conserve the Eastern black rhinoceros and their habitat. This project is intended to enhance Kenyas Eastern black rhinoceros population growth by addressing the impacts of poaching and the need for biological management. Specific activities include: (1) providing equipment and resources for aerial and ground protection; (2) monitoring to individually identify and regularly check on the black rhinoceros population; and (3) conducting biological management to allow for continued population growth.

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT A CONSERVATION EFFORT IN OL PEJETA CONSERVANCY AND SERA WILDLIFE CONSERVANCY IN KENYA BY IMPROVING MONITORING, BIOLOGICAL MANAGEMENT, RESILIENT HABITAT MANAGEMENT, AND LOCAL PARTNER ENGAGEMENT TO ENSURE THE CONTINUED RECOVERY OF BLACK RHINOCEROS AND THEIR HABITAT. THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE THE EASTERN BLACK RHINOCEROS AND THEIR HABITAT BY ADDRESSING THE IMPACTS OF POACHING, PREDATION, HABITAT DEGRADATION AND LOSS, AND ECONOMIC UNCERTAINTY CAUSED BY DROUGHTS, THE COVID 19 PANDEMIC, AND DECLINING TOURISM. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE (1) EQUIPPING RHINOCEROS MONITORING TEAMS (2) CONDUCTING BIOLOGICAL MANAGEMENT TO PROMOTE RHINOCEROS PRODUCTIVITY (3) ESTIMATING ECOLOGICAL CARRYING CAPACITY (4) ENSURING CONSISTENT WATER SUPPLY AND (5) ENGAGING WITH LOCAL COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO SUPPORT BLACK RHINOCEROS CONSERVATION EFFORTS.

title.narrative: PROMOTING SUSTAINED GROWTH OF EASTERN BLACK RHINO (DICEROS BICORNIS MICHAELI) POPULATIONS AT OL PEJETA AND SERA CONSERVANCIES, KENYA

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support a conservation effort in Ol Pejeta Conservancy and Sera Wildlife Conservancy in Kenya by improving monitoring, biological management, resilient habitat management, and local partner engagement to ensure the continued recovery of black rhinoceros and their habitat. This project is intended to conserve the Eastern black rhinoceros and their habitat by addressing the impacts of poaching, predation, habitat degradation and loss, and economic uncertainty caused by droughts, the COVID-19 pandemic, and declining tourism. Specific activities include: (1) equipping rhinoceros monitoring teams; (2) conducting biological management to promote rhinoceros productivity; (3) estimating ecological carrying capacity; (4) ensuring consistent water supply; and (5) engaging with local community members to support black rhinoceros conservation efforts.

title.narrative: REDUCING HUMAN-ELEPHANT CONFLICT IN THE IMENTI FOREST RESERVE AND RESTORING HABITAT CONNECTIVITY FOR THE WIDER ELEPHANT RANGE - PHASE 2

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support an elephant conservation effort in the Imenti Forest Reserve by.strengthening elephant protection and community engagement. Located within the Laikipia-Samburu.Ecosystem savanna elephant stronghold, the Imenti Reserve is part of the Mount Kenya protected area.complex, which is home to approximately 2,500 elephants. This project is intended to conserve African.savanna elephants and their habitat by addressing the impacts of human-elephant conflict (HEC) and.poaching. Specific activities include: (1) deploying anti-poaching patrols and installing a ranger.observation station; and (2) conducting a community survey to determine the most appropriate location.for elephant-proof short fencing and construction of the short fencing.

title.narrative: SAFEGUARDING ELEPHANT POPULATIONS IN SOUTHERN KENYA THROUGH COEXISTENCE AND CONNECTIVITY

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support an elephant conservation effort on community-owned land between Tsavo, Chyulu Hills,.and Amboseli National Parks, and Maasai Mara Reserve by strengthening elephant protection and community engagement, and.building a constituency for elephant conservation. As part of the Kenya Rift Valley savanna elephant stronghold, this ecosystem is.home to approximately 12,814 elephants. This project is intended to conserve African savanna elephants and their habitat by.addressing the impacts of poaching and human-elephant conflict (HEC). Specific activities include: (1) facilitating peer-to-peer.conservation learning and exchange among community and opinion leaders; (2) creating opportunities for conservation-related.investment in underfunded regions, including identification of potential tourism sites and developing proposals; (3) expanding.youth conservation leadership programming to schools located in key elephant corridors; (4) providing operational support and.community-based natural resource management (CBNRM) training to community rangers; and (5) conducting HEC mitigation.and rapid response interventions

title.narrative: ADVANCING ELEPHANT CONSERVATION AND WILDLIFE MIGRATORY ROUTES IN KENYA THROUGH STRENGTHENING COLLABORATION AND INCREASING LANDSCAPE CONNECTIVITY IN LAIKIPIA, KENYA.

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support an elephant conservation effort on private and community conservancy land in Laikipia.County by strengthening conservancy association coordination and organizational capacity, elephant protection, biological.monitoring, and community engagement. As part of the Laikipia-Samburu Ecosystem savanna elephant stronghold, this landscape.is home to Kenyas second largest elephant population, which includes approximately 7,000 individuals. This project is intended.to conserve African savanna elephants and their habitat by addressing the impacts of human-elephant conflict (HEC), poaching,.and habitat fragmentation. Specific activities include: (1) increasing staff and operational support to conservancy members; (2).creating a Corridor Management Committee and conducting stakeholder mapping and corridor consensus building with.communities; (3) establishing and fencing an elephant corridor and conducting wildlife monitoring; and (4) providing basic field.gear (boots, binoculars etc.) for ranger teams conducting anti-poaching patrols and monitoring the movements of elephants across.the corridor (cameras, phones etc.)

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPLEMENT CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES TO PROTECT THE PANCAKE TORTOISE FROM POACHING FOR THE PET TRADE AND DESTRUCTION OF ITS ROCK HABITAT. NATIVE ONLY TO KENYA AND TANZANIA, POPULATIONS OF THIS TORTOISE ARE DECREASING WIDELY THROUGHOUT ITS RANGE. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE (1)CONDUCTING POPULATION SURVEYS TO ASSESS ITS POPULATION STATUS WITHIN THE LEWA BORANA LANDSCAPE WHICH INCLUDES THREE PROTECTED AREAS (2) COLLECTING GENETIC SAMPLES TO DETERMINE POPULATION DIVERSITY (3) PREPARING A LANDSCAPE SCALE CONSERVATION MANAGEMENT PLAN AND (4) ANALYZING AND SHARING RECOMMENDATIONS AND CONSERVATION PLANS WITH NEARBY CONSERVANCIES AND PRIVATE RANCHES.

title.narrative: SURVEYING THE CRITICALLY ENDANGERED PANCAKE TORTOISE ON THREE PROTECTED WILDLIFE CONSERVANCIES IN KENYA TO ESTABLISH POPULATION RANGE EXTENSION AND DEVELOP LONG-TERM CONSERVATION STRATEGY

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to implement conservation activities to protect the pancake tortoise from poaching for the pet trade.and destruction of its rock habitat. Native only to Kenya and Tanzania, populations of this tortoise are decreasing widely.throughout its range. Activities include:.(1)conducting population surveys to assess its population status within the Lewa-Borana landscape which includes three protected.areas; (2) collecting genetic samples to determine population diversity; (3) preparing a landscape-scale conservation management.plan; and (4) analyzing and sharing recommendations and conservation plans with nearby conservancies and private ranches.
